author: sky.cactus
content: This is how we ended up with fear mongering MSM.  It gets clicks, and that trumps truth and journalistic integrity.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is why it is critical that we get everyone switched off of ETH2 nomenclature ASAP, because changing the way people speak is *really hard*.  I'm probably one of the biggest advocates against ETH2 nomenclature, and even I slip up from time to time.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: I guess usage of "eth2" as a term will naturally reduce after the Merge - does it matter what average users call it until then?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, because people will get scammed around the merge.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, names are very sticky, and there is no guarantee that people will stop calling it ETH2 after the merge.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: What kind of scam?

author: sky.cactus
content: Coinbase even has (or at least did last I checked) an ETH2 token, and people will buy ETH2 tokens on other exchanges thinking that is what they are getting when in reality they are getting some worthless piece of junk.

author: sky.cactus
content: The scam is people selling ETH2 coins to people who think there is a new blockchain coming out soon (pre merge), or just released (post merge).

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Oh okay. Does calling it "consensus and execution layers" help though?

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Users may not adopt nomenclature they dont understand

author: sky.cactus
content: The vast majority of people don't need to understand or use these terms.

author: sky.cactus
content: We just need to make it clear to users that there is not a new blockchain coming out, and not calling one tiny piece of Ethereum "ETH2" will help tremendously with that.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: But there are two chains right now - some users do need to know that.
